title: H1B Layoff to Comeback: The Quiet Route
summary: An Indian tech worker's successful transition from H1B to B2 visa following layoff highlights a potential path for laid-off visa holders in the US. The case study shows a successful change of status approval within 60 days, though the process remains uncertain and stressful for many in similar situations.
content:
In December 2024, hundreds of thousands of Indian technology employees in the United States faced the axe of layoff. For H1B visa holders, it wasn't merely losing employment—it meant a countdown to return home unless they managed to secure a chance to remain.

One popular route is going from H1B to a B2 tourist visa, only to stall. But that path is uncertain, particularly under new America, with an evolving immigration agenda.

Following a layoff in December, one Indian employee sought a B2 change of status (COS) in February 2025—and were approved early in April, all within 60 days. There were legitimate concerns that the B2 application could be delayed or denied, as many in the community are suspicious of this option.

In this instance, there were no RFEs (Requests for Evidence) issued on any of the petitions—the B2 COS and new H1B transfer were seamless. While this may be rare good fortune, it demonstrates the path's feasibility.

People often talk about backup plans, but rarely about the mental toll of living in legal limbo. It's stressful not knowing if you'll have to uproot your life and leave the country you've called home for years.

There's a need for clearer communication around visa options post-layoff. Currently, many rely on forums, rumors, and scattered advice to make life-changing decisions. Stories like this one provide hope but also highlight systemic gaps, where stability shouldn't depend on luck but should be built into the process.

markdown_content:
## The Impact of Tech Layoffs on Indian H1B Workers

In December 2024, hundreds of thousands of Indian technology employees in the United States faced the axe of layoff. For H1B visa holders, it wasn't merely losing employment—it meant a countdown to return home unless they managed to secure a chance to remain.

One popular route is going from H1B to a B2 tourist visa, only to stall. But that path is uncertain, particularly under new America, with an evolving immigration agenda.

## A Success Story

Following a layoff in December, one Indian employee sought a B2 change of status (COS) in February 2025—and were approved early in April, all within 60 days. There were legitimate concerns that the B2 application could be delayed or denied, as many in the community are suspicious of this option.

In this instance, there were no RFEs (Requests for Evidence) issued on any of the petitions—the B2 COS and new H1B transfer were seamless. While this may be rare good fortune, it demonstrates the path's feasibility.

## The Hidden Struggles

People often talk about backup plans, but rarely about the mental toll of living in legal limbo. It's stressful not knowing if you'll have to uproot your life and leave the country you've called home for years.

## The Need for Reform

There's a need for clearer communication around visa options post-layoff. Currently, many rely on:
* Forums
* Rumors
* Scattered advice

Stories like this one provide hope but also highlight systemic gaps, where stability shouldn't depend on luck but should be built into the process.
